channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Ministers unveil £76million package for domestic violence victims
item.description: Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick announced the funding as he took the daily Downing Street press briefing tonight.

item.title: UK announces hundreds more coronavirus deaths
item.description: NHS England confirmed another 370 COVID-19 victims in hospitals. Wales and Scotland both recorded 44 more fatalities each in the last 24 hours. Northern Ireland recorded 11 more deaths.

item.title: Margot Robbie, Scarlett Johansson, and Cameron Diaz have a showdown in their Boss B**** Fight video
item.description: Hollywood's biggest actresses joined together for a virtual fight video put on by stunt actress Zoë Bell and featuring Margot Robbie, Scarlett Johansson, Cameron Diaz, and Florence Pugh.

item.title: Sarah Ferguson dons a flower crown as she reads How About a Night Out? for Storytime with Fergie
item.description: The Duchess of York, 60 donned a floral crown as she read How About a Night Out? by Sam Williams for her YouTube series Storytime with Fergie and Friends.

item.title: Spaniards mob the streets as they're allowed out for the first time since March 15
item.description: Spaniards flocked to the streets today after being allowed out for the first time since the country introduced harsh lockdown measures to curb the spread of the coronavirus on 15 March.

item.title: 'I said goodbye through a nurse on the phone': Widow, 75, describes final words to husband
item.description: Pat Pearce, 75, asked a nurse to tell her husband Allan she was sorry she couldn't be with him and that she 'loved him very much' as he lay dying at University Hospital of Wales in Cardiff.

item.title: 'They're deluded': Farmer who took on 50 English workers to pick crops just has 7 left
item.description: Farmers have half as many workers picking the fields because seasonal pickers can't travel. Edward Spanton Farm in Kent (pictured) has just 40 of the 80 workers it would usually have.

item.title: Warm spell finally returns after a week of miserable downpours with temperatures set to soar to 65F
item.description: After a week of rain and thunderstorms the spring sunshine is due to return to Britain as temperatures reach as high as 65F this weekend. The weather will be drier for most with some scattered showers.

item.title: Lockdown horror as boy, 11, is shot in East London
item.description: A number of suspects had made off prior to the arrival of police at an address in Kerry Drive, Upminster at 9.30pm on Friday. where they found two people - a man and a boy - suffering injuries.

item.title: Britons flock outdoors in their thousands for the return of lockdown sunshine
item.description: Queues of customers began lining up at Homebase stores across the country this morning as the DIY chain reopened all of its nationwide branches.

item.title: More than 70 per cent of high street law firms face closure
item.description: A survey of 774 small legal firms by the Law Society found that 71 per cent may close their doors within six months as face-to-face meetings are increasingly difficult due to the Covid-19 lockdown.

item.title: Police arrest anti-lockdown protesters taking part in a 'group hug' outside Met's headquarters
item.description: An anti-lockdown activist has been arrested as protesters were seen taking part in a 'group hug' outside the Met Police's headquarters while holding signs with slogans such as 'my body my choice'.

item.title: Government testing chief plays down Matt Hancock's target amid row
item.description: John Newton brushed off a row over whether the numbers had been cooked, telling the BBC the big picture was capacity had risen and there would always be disputes when 'politicians set targets'.

item.title: A son called Wilfred Lawrie Nicholas
item.description: Carrie Symonds has revealed the name of her and Boris Johnson's newborn son is Wilfred, after Boris's grandfather, as the parents shared the first photograph of the baby boy on Instagram.

item.title: Yorkshire mother's heartbreak as she buries husband and daughter who died within days of each other
item.description: Former police officer and charity fundraiser David Whinchup, 79, and his daughter, Joanne Rennison, 52, from Cottingham, East Yorkshire, died just days apart.

item.title: Brits head to the TIP! Centres are heaving as councils try to stagger entry as part of phased return
item.description: There were long queues from as early as 8am this morning at dumps in Greater Manchester and Northumberland after local councils were given the green light to open tips today.

item.title: US Military scientists working on germ warfare make COVID-19 test
item.description: DARPA is making a new kind of coronavirus test that looks for an immune response to coronavirus. It may detect the virus much earlier than current diagnostics. DARPA has filed for FDA authorization.

item.title: Adorable moment ecstatic pensioner, 92, meets her great grandchild for the first time
item.description: Joan Cartwright, 92, was delighted after her grandson, Will and his wife, Jen, came round to introduce her to her sixth great-grandchild Holly. She leant out of her flat window in Horsforth, Leeds.

item.title: Silverstone boss Stuart Pringle warns British Grand Prix 'is not a given' even without spectators
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic has put Formula One's plans to start the season on hold but they races in Austria in early July before potentially two more at Silverstone are being lined up.

item.title: J.K Rowling donates £1million to charities on the 22nd anniversary of the Battle of Hogwarts
item.description: The Harry Potter author, 54, took to Twitter on Saturday to make the announcement, which she thought was fitting on the 22nd anniversary of the Battle of Hogwarts.

item.title: Councils in 'catastrophe': Town where HALF of workers face being furloughed pleads for PM's help
item.description: Gatwick Airport employs 3,500 people directly with a further 21,000 staff working at some of the 250 firms based at the campus. A further 12,000 jobs are supported indirectly.

item.title: Elon Musk's tweet caused Tesla's market value to tank by $14 billion
item.description: 'Tesla stock price is too high imo,' Musk tweeted on Friday, before going on to vow to sell off his physical possessions and recite part of the national anthem.

item.title: Bombshell US intelligence claims China lied about coronavirus outbreak
item.description: A leaked 15-page dossier from the 'Five Eyes' intelligence alliance states China's secrecy over the pandemic is an 'assault on international transparency'.

item.title: Twitter reacts to Kim Jong-un's return to public life
item.description: Twitter users reacted humorously to reports that Kim Jong-un had not died with one person using an image of WWE wrestler Mark William Calaway, better known as The Undertaker.

item.title: Britain's Gran Talent: Singer, 96, with Alzheimer's will become BGT's oldest ever contestant
item.description: Nora Barton, 96, who has Alzheimer's will tonight fulfil her dream of singing at the London Palladium - becoming the oldest ever contestant on Britain's Got Talent to boot - to prove life isn't for being put on hold.

item.title: Bride walks down aisle in empty church - with pews filled with pictures of congregants
item.description: Parris Khachi and Emily Manashi said 'I do' at San Francisco's St. Ignatius Church on Saturday. Only immediate family and a photographer were present, while others watched via livestream.

item.title: Prince William calls Boris Johnson after the Prime Minister welcomed son Wilfred
item.description: The Duke of Cambridge, 37, called Prime Minister Boris Johnson, 55, for a phone meeting on Friday afternoon, days after the politician welcomed his son Wilfred with fiancee Carrie Symonds, 32.

item.title: Stay with Dick and Angel at their Escape to the Chateau home
item.description: Dick and Angel Strawbridge are offering fans of Channel 4's Escape to the Chateau a chance to stay at their home as part of a new competition.

item.title: Hamptons home sells for $60million despite coronavirus pandemic as New York elite flee the city
item.description: The six-acre family compound, located in Southampton, New York, was initially put on the market in 2016, after its owner, financial advisory firm-founder John F. Sullivan, passed away.

item.title: Germany's daily coronavirus cases fall following five days of rising infections
item.description: Germany 's number of coronavirus cases has dropped following five days of rising infections after the government eased the country's lockdown measures earlier this week.

item.title: HMRC is 'inundated' with claims from employees working from home
item.description: Millions who are now working remotely due to the coronavirus pandemic are entitled to claim tax relief for items they say are 'wholly, exclusively and necessarily' to successfully do their job.

item.title: JONATHAN MAYO imagines 'the new normal' one year after Britain emerges from lockdown
item.description: Drawing on scientific predictions and the experiences of other countries to Britain emerging from isolation, JONATHAN MAYO imagines the 'new normal'.

item.title: Ford drive drags woman along road then tries to run her boyfriend over
item.description: Daniel Walmsley, 29, was arrested after footage went viral of him dragging a woman along a road in Newcastle and trying to run her boyfriend over. He was sentenced to over two years in jail.

item.title: Royal fans go wild over 'uncanny' resemblance between Princess Charlotte and Lady Sarah Chatto
item.description: Royal fans are going wild online over the 'uncanny' resemblance between Princess Charlotte, 5, in her new birthday portraits and the Queen's niece Lady Sarah Chatto's, 55.

item.title: People go wild over mouth-watering Vimto cocktail which is the perfect lockdown sweet treat
item.description: Kayleigh Snyder, from Essex, shared a snap of the Vimto cocktail and ingredients on the Extreme Couponing and Bargains UK group, sending social media users into a frenzy.

item.title: Police arrest two men on suspicion of stabbing NHS worker
item.description: The Metropolitan Police arrested a 19-year-old man in Stratford on Friday afternoon after arresting a 17-year-old boy in Telford, Shropshire, on suspicion of murdering NHS worker David Gomoh.

item.title: Commuters told to check temperatures before leaving home individual towns cities on lockdown
item.description: A loosening of certain restrictions designed to fire up the flagging economy will be accompanied with a roll-out of revamped social distancing guidelines, particularly on Britain's public transport.

item.title: The Body Coach Joe Wicks reveals he has come round following surgery
item.description: Joe Wicks has revealed he has woken up after undergoing a second operation on his hand at Kingston Hospital in London on Saturday.

item.title: Unions blast British Airways over its plan to send 12,000 staff 'to the dole'
item.description: Unison attacked British Airways accusing it of sending UK workers 'to the dole' after the airline confirmed it would not be seeking a bailout loan from the UK government.

item.title: Man, 41, charged with murdering pensioner, 88, in Surrey village appears in court
item.description: Darren John Robert McClean, 41, is accused of killing Dennis Kellond, 88, who was found dead on Monday in his £730,000 bungalow in picturesque Godstone, Surrey.

item.title: Some foods CAN be eaten after Best Before day by up to three years later, says government guidance
item.description: WRAP, which advises the government on waste, says tinned goods such as Heinz Beanz and soup, alongside pasta, jars of jam and meat, can be eaten up to three years after their expiration date.

item.title: The Queen and Prince Charles share their 'very best wishes' for Princess Charlotte's birthday
item.description: The Queen, 93, and Prince Charles, 72, were among the first to send their best wishes to Princess Charlotte on Instagram as she celebrates her fifth birthday at Anmer Hall in Norfolk today.

item.title: Check her out! Princess Charlotte dons sold-out Zara houndstooth dress with £12 leggings
item.description: Princess Charlotte, who is celebrating her fifth birthday today, wore the pretty Zara dress in the trendy and classic royal print as she delivered food to the vulnerable in Norfolk this week.

item.title: Secret military operation led by ex-Green Beret to ouster Venezuela's Maduro fails
item.description: A secret plan to send 300 heavily armed volunteers under the advisement of former Green Beret Jordan Goudreau to overthrow Venezuelan strongman Nicolás Maduro Moros has failed.

item.title: Statistician estimates almost double government figure but adjusting for excess deaths
item.description: The number of people in Britain who have died because of Covid-19 so far could be as high as 45,000, former ONS data analyst Jamie Jenkins has today warned.

item.title: Emma Thompson moves to Scotland house for lockdown days after getting Italian citizenship
item.description: Emma Thompson planned to move to Venice after Brexit because she felt European but moved to her Scotland house to stay in lockdown with her family just four days after getting Italian citizenship.

item.title: Mother fought off paedophile after he swung a knife demanding car keys as he is jailed for six years
item.description: Duncan Johnson, 41, demanded Natalie Grimes' keys at an Asda car park in Liverpool as he tried to rob a vehicle with her daughter, seven, inside. He was jailed for six years after the incident in March.

item.title: Reverend Richard Coles makes emotional radio tribute to sister-in-law who died from coronavirus
item.description: Reverend Richard Coles today invoked the Queen's 'we will meet again' message as he read out a touching tribute to his sister-in-law Louise Coles after her death from coronavirus.

item.title: People on lockdown share their most hilarious quarantine fails
item.description: People around the world are adapting to life under lockdown during the coronavirus pandemic but some have had to face hilarious set-backs, from mischievous felines to faulty hair equipment.

item.title: Meghan Markle: Multiple claims dismissed in Mail on Sunday case
item.description: The Duchess of Sussex, 38, is suing Associated Newspapers over an article which reproduced parts of a handwritten note she sent to Mr Markle, 75, in August 2018.

item.title: Common blood pressure pills DO NOT make coronavirus worse, three studies find
item.description: Doctors sounded the alarm in March after animal studies suggested the pills could warp the shape of human cells and make infection worse. But US researchers say there is no link.

item.title: FDA has APPROVED experimental drug Remdesivir for emergency use for coronavirus patients
item.description: President Donald Trump announced Friday that the FDA has approved the drug remdesivir for emergency use in hospitalized coronavirus patients.

item.title: Clever emoji quiz challenges users to guess the famous artist
item.description: Scottish Twitter user Gigs in Scotland took to social media to share the infuriating quiz, which challengers users to figure out the names of famous British artists, based on emojis.

item.title: The Holiday Guru answers questions on coronavirus travel rights
item.description: This week a reader also asks, in light of the pandemic, if they can claim back a 'non-refundable' deposit on a holiday lodge in Scotland.

item.title: Moscow's real coronavirus infection toll is more than 250,000 says the city's mayor
item.description: Moscow Mayor Segei Sobyanin, pictured visiting a specialist coronavirus hospital yesterday, wrote on his blog today that more than 250,000 people have the coronavirus.

item.title: Thousands of protesters stand off with mounted police as they swarm to Huntington Beach
item.description: Between 2,500 and 3,000 anti-lockdown protesters gathered near Huntington Beach boardwalk in California Friday in response to Gov. Gavin Newsom's closure of Orange County beaches.

item.title: New blood plasma Covid-19 treatment set to be trialled at London hospital
item.description: More than 140 NHS patients will be given the treatment at the London hospital in the coming weeks. It is hoped the antibody-rich plasma can bolster the immune system of critically unwell patients.

item.title: Alcoholics including one who hit rock bottom after almost dying reveal how they cope in lockdown
item.description: Former alcoholics tell FEMAIL what it's like to stay away from booze after hitting rock bottom - and offer words of hope to others who may be facing drink problems while coping with lockdown.

item.title: 'I can't wait to move!': Majority of buyers vow to crack on with moves
item.description: Getting the deal done looks set to become a tag-line for the property market as transactions remain on hold and more people look to move outside of big cities like London and Birmingham.

item.title: Gear up for a bike ride to Turkey - without leaving your sofa
item.description: The Daily Mail's Tom Chesshyre picks a selection of the best travel-related entertainment for the week ahead that will transport you to Istanbul, Mumbai and beyond.

item.title: Rolls-Royce 'is to cut up to 8,000 jobs' as coronavirus crisis hits income from air industry
item.description: British aero-engine maker Rolls-Royce is considering cutting up to 15 per cent of its workforce, a source told Reuters, as customers cut production and airlines park planes amid the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Kim Jong-Un makes his first public appearance for 20 days at a fertiliser plant
item.description: The despot cut the ribbon (pictured) at the opening of a fertiliser factory in Sunchon, state media reported, and released pictures supposedly showing the event.
item.media:credit: KCNA VIA KNS/AFP via Getty Image

item.title: Hong Kong police use pepper spray to clear May Day protest by more than 100 protesters
item.description: A group of 100 protesters met at the New Town Plaza mall in Hong Kong's New Territories, where they sang the protest anthem Glory to Hong Kong and chanted.

item.title: Calvin Harris is being 'SUED' by neighbour who accused him of leaking 'filthy water' from his home
item.description: Calvin Harris is reportedly being sued by his Bel Air neighbour who has accused him of 'leaking filthy water' out of his sprawling mansion.

item.title: Driving test centres with the highest and lowest first-time pass rates
item.description: With all driving tests suspended until 20 June due to coronavirus, there'll be a backlog of learners desperate to take their practical test. Here's where they have the best chance of passing first time.

item.title: Mum uses her one-year-old daughter to recreate movie scenes
item.description: Jessica Simpson, 32, from Cornwall, spends hours dressing up her 20-month-old daughter Evie in wigd and costumes to recreate movie and TV scenes, including Hellboy and Kill Bill.

item.title: You might need a splash of Mauritius magic after we get through all this!
item.description: Mark Twain once quoted a Mauritius local as saying that 'heaven was copied after Mauritius' after he visited in 1896. The Daily Mail's Kate Johnson headed to the island to see if it still rings true.

item.title: AMANDA PLATELL: Britain must not become a nation of snitches on neighbours
item.description: AMANDA PLATELL: We have always been a nation of curtain twitchers. But, who'd have thought nearly 200,000 people would report their neighbours for breaking lockdown rules?

item.title: Princess Charlotte, five today, drops off homemade pasta to vulnerable Norfolk residents
item.description: To mark her birthday, Kensington Palace has released new pictures of Charlotte (pictured) as she helped her parents deliver home-made pasta to vulnerable Norfolk residents in isolation.

item.title: New book reveals the dramas inside the walls of Kensington Palace
item.description: Very little escapes the notice of servants at Kensington Palace, writes TOM QUINN, the author of Kensington Palace: An Intimate Memoir from Queen Mary to Meghan Markle.

item.title: PAUL THOMAS on... The coronavirus 'R' value and Boris Johnson's new baby
item.description: To order a print of this Paul Thomas cartoon or one by Pugh, visit Mailpictures.newsprints.co.uk or call 0191 6030 178.

item.title: New mother who suffered five miscarriages reveals joy after giving birth to a healthy baby girl
item.description: Danielle Wilson, 24, from Peterborough, suffered a devastating five miscarriages and battled depression as she tried to fulfill her dream of becoming a mother.

item.title: The most divine British Isles! Magnificent coastal havens from Lundy to Newquay and St Kilda
item.description: Whether it's the setting of an Agatha Christie murder mystery, a puffin paradise or the former home of a crazed king, Britain is littered with tiny isles on which you can stay in seclusion.

item.title: Why is it so hard to buy a Nintendo Switch in lockdown?
item.description: Nintendo's Switch has ended up being one of the must-have items of the coronavirus panedmic lockdown. Consumer Trends has a look why.

item.title: Hundreds of children under the age of six were referred to the government's counterextremism scheme
item.description: More than 500 children under six were referred to the government-led programme which aims to challenge extremist ideologies and help children at risk of radicalisation.

item.title: Hundreds of Germans gather in Berlin to mark May Day despite ban on mass public gatherings
item.description: Police blocked roads around the square in Berlin's Kreuzberg district, traditionally the centre of left-wing May Day protests that had turned violent in the past, to prevent more people from joining.

item.title: Eton to spend £100m on educating disadvantaged children
item.description: Eton's headmaster, Simon Henderson, wants private schools to be on the right side of history after the coronavirus crisis and work towards closing the gap in education inequality with his £100m project.

item.title: Aviation tycoon seeks judicial review of the Covid-19 lockdown
item.description: Millionaire aviation tycoon Simon Dolan, pictured in 2011, has put the government on notice that he will seek a judicial review of the government's lockdown decision.

item.title: Oklahoma mall reopens for the first time since March with restrictions to prevent spread of COVID-19
item.description: Penn Square Mall in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, reopened for the first time since March with multiple restrictions in place designed to prevent the possible spread of the coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Man tests positive five weeks after symptoms end
item.description: Charles Pignal, 42, of Singapore, tested positive for coronavirus on March 4 and kept testing positive for the next 40 days even though his symptoms cleared in less than a week.

item.title: Coronavirus may increase risk of brain blood vessel blockages
item.description: The small study focused on six patients with confirmed COVID-19 and that had suffered a stroke caused by the sudden loss of blood circulation to the brain.

item.title: Costa Coffee will reopen another 29 stores across Britain for deliveries and drive-through orders
item.description: Four branches re-opened in Manchester and Bristol on April 24, a month after the lockdown began - but 12 delivery only and 17 drive-through stores will re-open today in Edinburgh, Glasgow, and Leeds.

item.title: National Trust stops cleaning rivers and may have to pause planting trees
item.description: The charity has called for 'renewal over mere recovery' and urges ministers to prioritise the climate after the pandemic crisis.

item.title: Many companies will keep in place changes made during coronavirus lockdown, study finds
item.description: Research by the Institute of Directors indicated there will also be a greater focus on digital services when the current lockdown ends. It revealed more are likely to pursue online training for staff.

item.title: Canada PM Justin Trudeau bans assault-style weapons after Nova Scotia mass shooting leaves 22 dead
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau cited numerous mass shootings in the country, including the rampage that killed 22 in Nova Scotia April 18 and 19, while banning more than 1,500 firearm models.

item.title: Lockdown lust files: Three quarters of Britons say social isolation benefited their relationships
item.description: An 'isolationship' survey asked 1,600 women how lockdown changed their relationships and lives. For Gemma Birkbeck, 32, lockdown has made her relationship with Kris Brook, 34, more intimate.

item.title: China censorship deleted critical coronavirus articles and social media posts written in Morse code
item.description: One deleted article about the situation in Wuhan (pictured) that caused particular outcry was typed out again and re-posted by dozens of social media users in 10 languages to test out censorship levels.

item.title: Film-maker Michael Moore's latest exposé raises host of troubling questions about the eco bandwagon
item.description: It's a pity that the emotional energy generated by the documentary Michael Moore Presents: Planet Of The Humans, can't be used on the national grid, writes TOM LEONARD.

item.title: Britain will begin formal negotiations with the US on a trade deal next week via video conference
item.description: Britain will kickstart formal negotiations with the U.S. on a trade deal next week. International Trade Secretary Liz Truss (pictured) will begin the talks with her American counterpart by video call.

item.title: Cardiff University students return to their halls to find their belongings thrown into bin bags
item.description: When some Cardiff University students returned to their Talybont South halls of residence they found some of their possessions had been thrown into bins during their absence (pictured)

item.title: EDEN CONFIDENTIAL: David Beckham's sister closes concierge business
item.description: RICHARD EDEN: As David Beckham's wife, Victoria, struggles to keep her fashion label going, his sister has been forced to admit defeat with her own business aimed at the rich and famous.

item.title: Previously-unseen photographs emerge of Iranian Embassy siege 40 years after the hostages were taken
item.description: Members of the SAS, a special regiment of the British Army, begin their assault on the Iranian Embassy in London, 40 years ago (pictured). New, unseen images have emerged of the siege.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are children more at risk than we've been told?
item.description: Ill children have been urgently referred to hospital with 'coronavirus-related syndrome', which has blood inflammation similar to Covid-19. Two-year-old Bertie Brown was not tested for the virus.

item.title: Re-usable PPE that could last for whole coronavirus pandemic could solve NHS shortages
item.description: The re-usable PPE, designed by British scientists and manufacturers, has the potential to replace throwaway items.

item.title: Scrubs actor Sam Lloyd dies at 56 after battling an inoperable brain tumor last year
item.description: Known for playing the downtrodden lawyer Ted Buckland on the show, Lloyd had been battling an inoperable brain tumor last year.

item.title: Sir Michael Palin reveals he set fire to his house and was rescued by 86-year-old neighbour
item.description: The Monty Python legend, 76, was recuperating at home after open-heart surgery in September to repair two valves.

item.title: Coronavirus: Drug trials could end lockdown before a vaccine
item.description: The potential new drugs provide a much quicker route out of the crisis than waiting for a vaccine, a paper published today by experts from Chelsea and Wesminster Hospital claims.

item.title: How cat allergies could soon be prevented by injecting pets
item.description: American company Indoor Biotechnologies have used a gene editing tool to eliminate the production of the protein in cats which causes some people to suffer allergic reactions.

item.title: Gordon Ramsay 'gets warning for flouting lockdown after being spotted miles from Cornwall bolthole'
item.description: Ramsay, 53, has been seen in Rock, Fowey, Port Isaac and Newquay - some distance from his £4million home in Trebetherick. Pictured: The alleged moment Ramsay ran the red light.

item.title: Asima Ali-Taha 34 originally from Sudan goes missing in Bristol as police seek man on phone
item.description: Asima Ali-Taha, 34, was last seen in Counterslip, Bristol at around 3pm on April 24.

item.title: Border Force officers in France seize £20million worth of cocaine
item.description: The haul, which had a potential street value of around £20 million, was discovered within a number of plywood boxes in a lorry carrying a consignment of car parts.

item.title: Normal People laid bare: Between the sheets of the BBC hit
item.description: Normal People tells the story of Marianne (right) and Connell (left), who fall in love in sixth form, and charts their on-off relationship through university. The series is being hailed as 'perfect'.

item.title: Holidaymakers face six-month wait for refunds as airlines struggle with backlog with £7billion owed
item.description: Millions of travellers are owed money for cancelled flights amid the coronavirus pandemic. EU laws say customers should get refunds in seven days but backlogs mean they are waiting longer.

item.title: Forget swanky kitchens, a pantry will make your butter and potatoes taste better
item.description: Thinking about it now, the place I was happiest as a child was in my mother's larder. It was that special room where you could cool your bare feet in summer; always dimly lit by a small window.

item.title: DR MAX THE MIND DOCTOR: Don't fall victim to furlough Merlot
item.description: If you have found yourself reaching for a soothing glass of wine or three, or a hefty gin and tonic each night during lockdown, then DR MAX THE MIND DOCTOR has some tips for you.

item.title: Sunny April weather could mean a bumper apple harvest this autumn, says National Trust
item.description: April's sunny weather could mean a bumper apple harvest this autumn says the National Trust, which cares for more than 200 orchards across England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

item.title: JOHN HUMPHRYS says the coronavirus crisis has been a tragedy but has had many benefits
item.description: JOHN HUMPHRYS: The pandemic has changed our way of life dramatically and we're starting to get the hang of it and even, dare I say it, enjoy it.

item.title: Window washers fly through the air as winds of 47mph hit their platform during sudden Florida storm
item.description: The incident, which was caught on video by people standing on a nearby balcony, took place on Thursday afternoon, at the Ritz-Carlton Residences in Sunny Isles Beach, Florida.

item.title: Robert Hardman says Sir Winston Churchill would be proud of £5million Mail Force donations
item.description: ROBERT HARDMAN: I have no doubt Sir Winston Churchill (pictured outside Downing Street in April 1945) would be equally moved by the magnificent response to the call to arms by Mail Force.

item.title: How Alan Titchmarsh felt 'teary' after garden centre owner gives away £500,000 worth of plants
item.description: TV gardener Alan Titchmarsh thought 'it was the nicest thing' when Kirton Farm Nurseries, of Winchester, started handing out free flowers to households in Hampshire rather than bin them.

item.title: Gardeners' World enjoys its highest viewing figures in a decade because of lockdown
item.description: The BBC2 show, which saw Monty Don self-filming footage from his garden, drew an audience of 2.7million on April 24 as the programme was made for the first time by a socially-distanced crew.

item.title: Priti Patel admits 7% rise in knife crime is 'appalling' and says Sadiq Khan 'should be doing more'
item.description: Home Secretary Priti Patel said an overall fall in recorded crime could not mask the misery caused by a sharp rise in knife offences in England and Wales, which are at a record high.

item.title: Easy one-pan bacon, egg, and cheese breakfast sandwich hack goes viral
item.description: TikTok users are going wild after a home cook from New Jersey shared a very clever way to make a bacon, egg, and cheese breakfast sandwich - all in one pan in just a few minutes.

item.title: Remarkable black and white images capture the stores along historic Route 66 during the 1950s
item.description: A cache of stunning images of historic Route 66 during the 1950s were unearthed after the death of Charles Custer, a Chicago resident who had taken them on early road trips with his wife.

item.title: VE Day flypast will go over Care for Veterans home, NHS hospital and Colonel Tom Moore's house
item.description: Our Spitfire Mk IX, donated by the Goodwood-based Boultbee Spitfire Academy, will take to the skies in tribute to the British veterans.

item.title: BEL MOONEY: Is my son unfaithful because of his dad's cheating?
item.description: This week Bel advises a reader who is afraid her son's extra-marital affair is a result of his own father's cheating.

item.title: Is this the future of travel? From blood tests during check-in to plastic booths around plane seats
item.description: The only certainty is that the future of travel is uncertain. We'll all have to get used to a whole new travel landscape once coronavirus restrictions are lifted. So what will it look like?

item.title: U.S. says Maduro regime is linked to $165million worth of cocaine seized off Spain's coast
item.description: Spain's military seized a vessel April 25 that crossed the Atlantic Ocean with 4.4 tons of cocaine that were loaded off the coast of Venezuela earlier in the month.

item.title: Tom Watson went on lobbying mission with former UK Music boss two years before becoming chairman
item.description: The row over Tom Watson's appointment to a top music industry job intensified after it emerged he went on a lobbying mission with the former head of the organisation he now chairs.

item.title: Mail Force PPE donations reach £5million as facemasks land at UK hospices
item.description: Staff at the Mountbatten Hampshire centre said they were 'overwhelmed' by last night's delivery of thousands of life-saving masks and coveralls.

item.title: Funds to defend your savings from the market rout
item.description: In future, more people may want to preserve their money, rather than maximise returns. Fund managers like Jonathan Ruffer who are committed to safeguarding could become power players.

item.title: ALEX BRUMMER: Why were life sciences firms left out of the loop?
item.description: What Britain's fight against coronavirus has shown is the monolithic approach of Public Health England at the outset of the crisis was a terrible error, which frustrated the medical research community.

item.title: Heartbreaking photographs reveal doctors and nurses working a 12-hour night shift
item.description: Photographer Christopher Bobyn of Nine, BBC News Scotland was granted exclusive access to the NHS ICU at Hairmyres hospital, in East Kilbride Scotland over a period of 12 hours.
item.media:credit: Christopher Bobyn - Photos courtesy of the Nine, BBC Scotland

item.title: Trump claims Joe Biden could face MORE women 'coming out'
item.description: President Donald Trump on Friday predicted more accusers would come out against Joe Biden and said he was 'sticking up' for the former vice president.

item.title: Court orders Volkswagen to pay £3million after ruling it installed unlawful 'defeat devices' in cars
item.description: Volkswagen was refused permission to appeal against a damning High Court ruling saying it installed unlawful 'defeat devices' in thousands of its diesel cars. Around 90,000 motorists took legal action.
item.media:description: VW will be pursuing an appeal directly to the Court of Appeal (Gareth Fuller/PA)

item.title: Real call of nature: Homeowners report frogs are emerging through sinks and toilets
item.description: Three separate Chesterfield addresses have reported finding frogs (pictured) coming out of of their sinks, toilets and drains, fearing that the creatures have 'infiltrated their water systems'.

item.title: Russia says 'faster' robots will overtake soldiers on the battlefield in the near future
item.description: Russian researcher Vitaly Davydov has said robots will overtake their human brothers on the battlefield because they will be faster and are more accurate in target selection.

item.title: Spectacular pictures reveal a centuries-old royal family golden seal
item.description: Amazing images showed a centuries-old royal family golden seal weighing over 17 pounds unearthed by Chinese archaeologists studying the remnants of a Ming dynasty battlefield on Tuesday.

item.title: Half of rice sold in the UK breaches limits on arsenic for children
item.description: A total of 28 out of 55 varieties included in a study conducted by the University of Sheffield breached the 0.1 mg kg−1 limit laid out by the EU, to which the UK adheres.

item.title: Christian fostering agency takes Ofsted to the High Court over 'discrimination' claims
item.description: Cornerstone (North East) Adoption and Fostering Service, which operates in the North East of England, is taking watchdog Ofsted to court claiming it is being forced to abandon its religious ethos.

item.title: Moment policewoman breaks down in tears after thug spits BLOOD in her eye
item.description: Temisan Oritsejafor, 41, launched the sickening attack on PC Annie Napier who was detaining him after he assaulted his neighbour in in Wyken, Coventry.
